Guangzhou Institute of Chemistry Chinese Academy of Sciences Guangzhou 510650 PR China Epoxidized soybean oil (ESO) is a vital organic renewable chemical material widely used in the preparation of biomaterials. In this paper, a novel amphiphilic phase transfer catalyst [(C18H37)2(CH3)2N]3{PO4[W(O)(O2)2]4} was developed to facilitate the green, safe and sustainable production of ESO, with the aim of achieving maximum environmental and economic benefits. Soybean oil (SBO) was epoxidized into ESO at a conversion rate of 98.6% and the selectivity of this process was above 99% with H2O2 as the oxidant. The catalyst was easily separable through filtration after the reaction, and its activity was found to be consistently maintained after 5 cycles. The developed catalysts were characterized via various physical means such as Fourier-transform infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopy, X-ray diffraction (XRD), and scanning electron microscopy (SEM), while the catalytic mechanism was explored using FT-IR spectroscopy. Several kinetic and thermodynamic experiments suggested that the developed catalyst possessed significant interfacial activity and the process followed a non-spontaneous endothermic pathway. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Amphiphilic phase transfer catalyst Epoxidation Catalytic mechanism Interfacial activity Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Epoxidized soybean oil (ESO) is a significant organic renewable chemical raw material with diverse applications in biomaterials [1–3]. So far, ESO is produced industrially via the Prilezhaev reaction, which occurs by the epoxidation of soybean oil (SBO) with an in situ-generated percarboxylic acid in the presence of H2O2 and H2SO4 [4]. However, these reagents are inexpensive but demand specialized equipment and safety measures due to their corrosive and toxic nature. Also, the exothermic oxidation of percarboxylic acids is challenging to control the temperature on an industrial scale and can lead to a thermal runaway reaction in the production process [5,6]. Moreover, the addition of inorganic acid as a co-catalyst to reduce the pH leads to ring-opening reactions of ESO, thereby limiting its selectivity [7,8]. Consequently, there is a necessity to explore safer, more economical, and environmentally friendly production processes for ESO. Hydrogen peroxide is an excellent oxidizer that has gained tremendous attention in recent decades due to its non-toxic nature and low environmental impact, as it only produces water as a by-product [9–11]. In the oxidation of olefins, the mild oxidation capacity of hydrogen peroxide necessitates exploring catalysts with high performance [9]. Several catalysts have been developed for olefin epoxidation using hydrogen peroxide, including acidic exchange resins [12–14], peroxotungstates [15–17], polyoxometalates [18,19], transition-metal complexes [20,21] and lipases [22–24]. Compared to the epoxidation of short-chain olefins' terminal double bonds, the epoxidation of unsaturated bonds of long-chain fatty acids that contain terminal carboxylic acid groups can be a more challenging task [25,26]. Additionally, reports have indicated that without a catalyst, H2O2 does not exhibit any reactivity with oil or fat [8,27]. Therefore, it is crucial to develop a catalyst that efficiently transfers active oxygen between the two phases. Previous studies have developed substitute acidic exchange resins for inorganic acids used in the Prilezhaev process [28–30]. However, while they exhibit advantages such as inhibited side reactions and facile separation, they do not overcome the primary drawbacks of the process, including its corrosiveness, toxicity, and poor selectivity. Similarly, the process developed for lipase as a catalyst for fatty acid epoxidation reactions has drawbacks such as high cost, long reaction times, and difficulty in post-treatment [31–33]. Moreover, when CoCuAl layered double hydroxides prepared by co-precipitation are used as catalysts for fatty acid epoxidation reactions, epoxidized oils' conversion rates only reach 50–70% [34]. Although commercial Al2O3 is active in SBO epoxidation reactions, it is exceptionally susceptible to the decomposition of H2O2 [35,36]. None of the catalysts used in the reaction systems mentioned above are ideal targets. Direct epoxidation of SBO with H2O2 to produce ESO is a green and cost-effective methodology that exhibits high selectivity without generating carboxylic acids, and the only by-product, water, is non-toxic to the environment. Therefore, exploring new catalysts to produce ESO at high yield and with high selectivity under solvent-free conditions is highly desirable. During the search for a better catalyst, Venturello et al. discovered that peroxophosphotungstate was active for double bond epoxidation with H2O2 [37]. To overcome the immiscibility of H2O2 with the reactants (fatty acids, esters or triglycerides), the active peroxophosphotungstate species (PO4[W(O)(O2)2]4)3− can be combined with cationic phase transfer agents [38]. This reaction system prevents the risk of overheating hazards and provides higher selectivity and lower toxicity than the Prilezhaev system. Unfortunately, this system is not economically feasible because the catalyst is dispersed homogeneously and, hence, not recyclable. In recent years, two commonly reported approaches have been used to design a soluble phase transfer agent in the system. The first approach is to select a cationic carrier that makes the catalytic complex inhomogeneous, such as polymers derived from ionic liquids [39–41], functionalized silica [42], or magnetic iron oxide nanoparticles [43–45]. The second approach is to immobilize a complex of peroxophosphotungstate and phase transfer agents in a substrate, such as mesoporous silica [46,47], metal-organic frameworks [48,49], or metal carriers [50–53]. Masteri-Farahani et al. performed several studies on immobilizing peroxyphosphotungstate in nanomaterials as part of a multi-phase catalyst for the oxidation of double bonds, and their findings indicated that all of the catalysts exhibit excellent performance [54,55]. However, Luis et al. conducted a study on the epoxidation rate of double bonds using different non-homogeneous catalysts, and their results revealed that the reaction rates of non-homogeneous catalysts are an order of magnitude slower than those of homogeneous catalysts [38]. To be economical, both activity and recyclability of these catalysts will need to be improved so that they can be used as alternatives to percarboxylic acids. In this study, we synthesized a novel amphiphilic phase transfer catalyst, [(C18H37)2(CH3)2N]3{PO4[W(O)(O2)2]4}, using a green and facile method. We paired a dimethyldioctadecylammonium chloride cation as a phase transfer agent with a peroxophosphotungstate anion. The catalyst demonstrated a reaction rate consistent with that of homogeneous catalysts in the solvent-free epoxidation reaction of SBO with H2O2. It was easily recoverable by filtration and could be easily synthesized from commercial reagents. Additionally, various physical techniques such as Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR), X-ray diffraction (XRD), and scanning electron microscopy (SEM) were employed to characterize the obtained catalysts, while the FT-IR spectroscopy was used to investigate the catalytic mechanism. Finally, we studied the kinetic and thermodynamic properties of the catalyst through a series of experiments, including the effects of the catalyst amount, temperature, stirring rate, and catalyst reusability. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Dimethyldioctadecylammonium chloride ((C18H37)2(CH3)2NCl, 97%), phosphotungstic acid (H3PW12O40·xH2O, ≥ 99.0%), absolute ethanol (CH3CH2OH, ≥ 99.7%), and acetone (CH3COCH3, 99%) were purchased from Aladdin Reagent Co., Ltd. Soybean oil (SBO) and hydrogen peroxide (H2O2, 50%) were kindly provided by Shengjun Material Technology Co., Ltd. Deionized water was used for the experimental procedures. 2.2 Preparation of [(C18H37)2(CH3)2N]3{PO4[W(O)(O2)2]4} To synthesize the catalyst, we first added an appropriate amount of 50% H2O2 to a 150 mL round-bottom flask containing 2.88 g (1 mmol) of H3PW12O40·xH2O and stirred the mixture for 1.5 h at 40 °C. Next, we dissolved 1.76 g (3 mmol) of (C18H37)2(CH3)2NCl in anhydrous ethanol and added it to the mixture at room temperature with continued stirring. The resulting suspension solution exhibited a white precipitate and was stirred for an additional 3 h. We obtained the white precipitate via suction filtration and then washed it with deionized water and CH3CH2OH. Finally, we dried the white precipitate in a vacuum oven at 60 °C for 8 h, yielding approximately 2.59 g (92.5 % yield). Scheme 1 illustrates the synthesis route of the catalyst. 2.3 Epoxidation of SBO The following general procedure was used: SBO (30 g) was mixed with a catalyst (0.3 g) in a 250 mL three-necked round-bottom flask, and placed in a temperature-controlled oil bath with a stirrer under constant speed. The oil temperature was maintained at 60 °C in this mixture, and H2O2 (12.24 g) was added dropwise into the round-bottom flask via a peristaltic pump at a constant flow rate over a period of 15 min. This reaction occurred at 300 rpm for 4 h, after which the mixture was cooled to room temperature. The mixture was then separated by centrifugation in a centrifuge tube and the upper organic phase (ESO) was collected for iodine value (IV) and epoxy value (EV) analysis (In the Supplementary Information) [26], and the remaining mixture was filtered to recover the catalyst. The SBO's conversion and selectivity were calculated via Eqs. (1) and (2): (1) C o n v e r s i o n ( % ) = I V 0 − I V I V 0 × 100 % (2) Selectivity ( % ) = = E V × I V 0 E V 0 × ( I V 0 − I V ) × 100 % where I V 0 refers to the iodine value of SBO (g/100 g of oil); E V 0 refers to the theoretical maximum epoxy value of ESO (%), and I V and E V are the iodine value and epoxy value of the product (ESO), respectively. The catalyst's turnover frequency (TOF) was calculated by Eq. (3). (3) TOF ( h − 1 ) = n 0 ( S B O ) × C o n v e r s i o n × S e l e c t i v i t y n ( c a t a l y s t ) × t i m e where n 0 ( S B O ) represents the molar amount of the initial SBO (mol); n ( c a t a l y s t ) represents the mole amount of catalyst used (mol), and t i m e represents the reaction time (h). 2.4 Characterization To characterize the chemical structure of the catalyst, an FT-IR spectrometer (Thermo Scientific iN10, USA) was employed. The FT-IR spectra were collected using the KBr pellet method and the transmittance mode within a wavenumber range of 4000–600 cm−1. Additionally, during the epoxidation reaction, FT-IR spectra of SBO and ESO were recorded using an FT-IR spectrometer (Thermo Scientific Nicolet iS20, USA) within a wavenumber range of 3500–600 cm−1. The catalysts' crystal structures were obtained using X-ray diffraction (XRD) on a Rigaku Smartlab 9 KW instrument (Japan). The patterns were recorded within a 2θ range of 0° to 80°. The microstructure was then analyzed using scanning electron microscopy (SEM) on gold-plated samples with an operating voltage of 15 kV, using a Tescan MIRA LMS instrument from the Czech Republic. To characterize the synthesized catalysts, nuclear magnetic resonance phosphorus spectroscopy (31P NMR) was employed, utilizing an Avance NEO 400 MHz instrument from Bruker (Germany). The Jarrell-Ash 1100 ICP-AES spectrometer (USA) was used to measure the quantity of tungsten species leached in the filtrate. 2.5 Kinetics and thermodynamics studies A kinetic model was developed for the epoxidation reaction of SBO using heterogeneous catalysts, based on previous research [56,57]. To investigate the kinetic information, including the reaction rate constant, activation energy, and frequency factor, the reaction rate was correlated with the reaction temperature. The stoichiometric equation of the SBO epoxidation reaction process is shown in Eq. (4): (4) S B O + 5 H 2 O 2 → E S O + 5 H 2 O where SBO and ESO denote soybean oil and epoxidized soybean oil, respectively. The essence of this SBO epoxidation system is the reaction of unsaturated double bonds with hydrogen peroxide, so the chemical equation can be written as Eq. (5). (5) C = C + H 2 O 2 → + H 2 O Based on Eq. (5), it is evident that the reaction rate is dependent on the concentrations of the double bond and H2O2 in the reaction system. Since there is an excess of hydrogen peroxide in the system, its concentration is assumed to remain constant throughout the reaction. Thus, the reaction rate depends solely on the concentration of the double bond. Taking this into account, a first-order kinetic equation is more appropriate for this reaction, as shown in Eq. (6) for the rate equation. (6) d [ C = C ] d t = − k [ C = C ] where [ C = C ] denotes the concentration of the double bond and k was the rate constant at a particular temperature. From mass balance, (7) X E S O = 1 − [ C = C ] t [ C = C ] 0 So, (8) [ C = C ] t = [ C = C ] 0 × ( 1 − X E S O ) where X E S O referred to the ESO conversion. Integrating Eq. (6) and obtain the following Eq. (9): (9) − l n ( 1 − X E S O ) = k × t Eq. (9) is used to determine the rate constant of the reaction. Furthermore, the reaction activation energy is calculated using the Arrhenius equation, and taking the logarithm of both sides of this equation, as shown in Eq. (10): (10) lnk = lnA − E a R T where A was the Arrhenius constant, and R was the ideal gas law constant (8.314 J K−1 mol−1). The enthalpy of activation ( Δ H # ) and entropy of activation ( Δ S # ) are determined by regressing l n ( k / T ) versus 1 / T (K−1), and this regression equation explains the reaction rate of the basic chemical reaction, as shown in Eq. (11) [58]: (11) ln ( k / T ) = [ ln ( k b h ) + ( Δ S # R ) ] − ( Δ H # RT ) where Δ H # and Δ S # are the activation enthalpy and activation entropy, respectively, h denotes the Planck constant (6.626 × 10−34 J s), and k b is the Boltzmann constant (1.38 × 10−23 J K−1). The Gibb's free energy ( Δ G # ) was determined according to Eq. (12) [59]: (12) Δ G # = Δ H # − T Δ S # 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Optimization of the catalyst synthesis The objective of this study was to develop an amphiphilic phase transfer agent that provides sufficient hydrophilic interactions to regenerate the active peroxophosphotungstate species with H2O2, as well as sufficient lipophilic affinity to react with the substrate, while still maintaining limited leaching of the catalyst for recoverability. According to prior research, quaternary ammonium cations with complex carbon chain structures help to enhance the stability of phosphotungstate ions [60]. Therefore, we chose (C18H37)2(CH3)2NCl to undergo ion exchange with H3PW4O24. Prior to ion exchange, it was essential to oxidize phosphotungstic acid with H2O2 to form a peroxide in order to obtain the active catalyst. The active substance in the reaction is usually considered to be {PO4[W(O)(O2)2]4}3- [37], which precipitated from the solution when paired with a lipophilic transfer agent. However, co-products (H2WO4 or H2WO6) are generated during this reaction, which also paired with lipophilic transfer agents to form precipitates, thus impeding efforts to purify the target [38]. To optimize catalyst synthesis, we explored the effects of the ratio of H2O2 to H3PW12O40·xH2O and the ratio of (C18H37)2(CH3)2NCl to H3PW12O40·xH2O. The activity of the obtained catalysts was evaluated in terms of the epoxidation of SBO with H2O2 at 60°C under solvent-free conditions (Table 1 ). To begin with, we conducted SBO epoxidation reactions using the catalysts prepared with different ratios of H2O2 to H3PW12O40·xH2O (Table 1, entries 1-2). Based on our results, the catalysts prepared with 200 eq. of H2O2 showed better conversion rates and selectivity. We also performed 31P NMR spectra of the catalysts separately, as shown in Fig. 1 . Fig. 1a revealed that the catalyst prepared with 20 eq. of H2O2 (entry 1) had eight central peaks, where the single peaks at -12.7 ppm and -15.4 ppm were identifiable as PW11O39 7− and PW12O40 3−, respectively [9,61]. This result suggested that 20 eq. of H2O2 was insufficient to completely degrade the phosphotungstic acid. In addition, previous research by Aubry et al. confirmed that a lack of sufficient amounts of H2O2 in phosphotungstic acid leads to the production of H2WO4, which catalyzes the hydrolysis of epoxides and impairs selectivity [62]. This was supported by the low selectivity observed in the SBO epoxidation reaction in entry 1. Thus, we opted to use 200 eq. of H2O2 for subsequent oxidation reactions with phosphotungstic acid. A larger amount of H2O2 would completely oxidize the by-product H2WO4 to produce H2WO6 [38]. Although WO6 2− combined with a cation to form a co-precipitate, it did not affect the selectivity of the catalyst. Notably, the 31P NMR spectra of the prepared catalyst (Fig. 1b) demonstrated that 200 eq. of H2O2 was sufficient to degrade the phosphotungstic acid. Gao et al. discovered that PW12O40 3− had decomposed into various peroxy species with low W/P ratios such as {(PO4)[WO(O2)2]2[WO(O2)2(H2O)]}3−, [(PO4)[WO(O2)2]4]3− and {[PO3(OH)][WO(O2)2]2}2− in the presence of H2O2 [63]. The multiple central peaks appearing in Fig. 1b were attributed to these peroxy species. Next, we investigated the impact of the (C18H37)2(CH3)2NCl/H3PW12O40·xH2O ratio on catalytic performance. Initially, we tested a "natural" ratio of 3:1, which provided excellent conversions and selectivities of 98.1% and 99.2%, respectively, when catalyzing the SBO epoxidation reaction (Entry 2, Table 1). However, when an excess of (C18H37)2(CH3)2NCl was added (Entry 3, Table 1), the conversion rate had decreased to 54.1%, as (C18H37)2(CH3)2NCl paired with a significant amount of inactive by-product WO6 2− to form a co-precipitate, which contaminated the catalyst and decreased its activity. Interestingly, the catalyst's activity significantly increased when excess H3PW12O40·xH2O was introduced (Entry 4, Table 1). Consequently, the catalyst loading could be reduced from 2 wt% to 1 wt%. Under these conditions, conversion and selectivity values of 98.6% and 99.6% were respectively obtained, and the TOF was also dramatically enhanced to 104.8 h−1. The catalyst's 31P NMR spectrum (Fig. 1c) showed a sharp peak at 1.1 ppm, indicating that {PO4[W(O)(O2)2]4}3− was the primary active component of the catalyst. We also observed that the rate of (C18H37)2(CH3)2NCl addition affected the catalyst's activity. Since the solvent used was polar (a mixture of CH3CH2OH, H2O2, and water), the higher charge density of {PO4[W(O)(O2)2]4}3− would bind to the cationic (C18H37)2(CH3)2N+ faster than would be the case with WO6 2−. The slowly adding (C18H37)2(CH3)2NCl enhanced the difference in the reaction rate between ions, facilitating the production of active substances. Finally, we also conducted catalytic experiments using H3PW12O40·xH2O without ammonium ions (C18H37)2(CH3)2N+ (Entry 5, Table 1). The results demonstrated a conversion of 15.3% and a selectivity of 79.3% for the SBO epoxidation. This result was primarily attributed to the challenge of transferring the reactive oxygen species from the aqueous phase to the oil phase in the absence of ammonium ions. 3.2 Characterization of [(C18H37)2(CH3)2N]3{PO4[W(O)(O2)2]4} Fig. 2 displays the FT-IR spectra of the catalyst developed and H3PW12O40·xH2O in this study. The peaks observed at 1060, 953, 841, 549, 885, and 815 cm−1 corresponded to the anti-symmetric vibrational absorption peaks of P-O, W=O, O-O, W(O)2 and W-Od-W in corner shared octahedron, and the anti-symmetric vibrational absorption peak of W-Oc-W in the edge-shared octahedron, as reported by Song et al. [64]. This result indicates the presence of a Keggin structure in the chemical structure of the catalyst [9]. The absorption peaks located at 720, 1469, 2850 and 2920 cm−1 corresponded to quaternary cations, while the absorption peaks at 2850 and 2920 cm−1 were derived from methylene and methyl groups, respectively [65]. To gain further insight into the chemical structure of the catalyst, XRD analysis was performed separately on [(C18H37)2(CH3)2N]3{PO4[W(O)(O2)2]4} and H3PW12O40·xH2O, as shown in Fig. 3 . The X-ray diffraction pattern obtained for the catalyst displayed a distinct peak at 2θ = 21°, which is indicative of the Keggin structure [66]. However, the remaining peaks were weak and broad, suggesting that the prepared catalyst was poorly crystalline and predominantly amorphous [67]. The long alkyl chains present in the catalyst likely hindered the formation of any well-ordered crystalline phase of the Keggin unit. Moreover, SEM analysis was conducted on both the catalyst and feedstock. Fig. 4 a depicts the layered structure of (C18H37)2(CH3)2NCl, while Fig. 4b showcases the smooth surface of H3PW12O40·xH2O. On the other hand, Fig. 4c displays the rock-like structure of the catalyst, which is believed to be caused by the attachment of (C18H37)2(CH3)2NCl onto the surface of H3PW12O40·xH2O. Finally, thermogravimetric (TGA) and differential thermal (DTA) analysis were conducted on H3PW12O40·xH2O and [(C18H37)2(CH3)2N]3{PO4[W(O)(O2)2]4} to investigate their thermal stability. The TGA curve of H3PW12O40·xH2O (Fig. 5 a) exhibited a decrease in mass accompanied by heat release in the temperature range from room temperature to 190°C, primarily due to the loss of water. In the TGA-DTA curve of the catalyst (Fig. 5b), an additional exothermic mass reduction was observed in the region of 250-400°C, which can be attributed to the decomposition of hydrocarbons in the catalyst [68]. This weight loss of approximately 60% also corresponded consistently with the hydrocarbon mass fraction in the catalyst. 3.3 Catalytic performance SBO is composed of a mixture of saturated and unsaturated fatty acid triglycerides. Its main components are palmitic, oleic, and linoleic acid. The iodine value (IV0 ) of the SBO used in this study was 126.8 ± 0.4 g, indicating a double bond content of 0.4996 ± 0.0016 mol per 100 g of SBO. The compositions and properties of the fatty acids in SBO are described in Table 2 [69]. The acid value was used to measure the amount of free fatty acids present in the SBO, which is expressed as the amount of potassium hydroxide required to neutralize 1 g of SBO. 3.3.1 Effect of the amount of catalyst We conducted an investigation into the epoxidation of SBO using an equimolar double-bonded amount of H2O2 (0.05mol H2O2/10 g SBO) at 60 °C for 3 h. The study examined various amounts of catalyst, with the catalyst to SBO mass ratios set at 1/200, 1/150, 1/100, 1/75, and 1/50, respectively. As depicted in Fig. 6 a, the SBO conversion rate progressively increased from 61.2% to 98.6% as the catalyst mass ratio rose from 1/200 to 1/50, with selectivity remaining above 98%. This demonstrates that the dosage of catalyst used has a significant impact on SBO conversion, as it reflects the number of active sites on the catalyst surface. Using a greater amount of catalyst makes it easier for the SBO to undergo the epoxidation reaction. Considering the conversion of the SBO and production economics, we opted for a catalyst-to-SBO mass ratio of 1/100 for the subsequent temperature and recycling experiments. 3.3.2 Effect of reaction temperature The reaction temperature played a crucial role in achieving the desired conversion in the epoxidation reaction, as the optimal temperature provided the energy needed to overcome the barrier of threshold energy [70]. Additionally, the viscosity of SBO was closely linked to temperature, with increasing temperature enhancing the mass transfer rate of the reactants in the system. To examine the epoxidation of SBO using an equimolar double-bonded amount of H2O2 (0.05 mol H2O2/10 g SBO) in the presence of the catalyst, we performed experiments at 40, 50, 60, 70, and 80 °C for 3 h, respectively. As illustrated in Fig. 6b, the conversion of SBO increased with rising temperature, reaching 99% at 80 °C. However, its selectivity decreased to 94.1% at 80 °C due to ESO degradation at high temperatures [8]. Hence, the optimal temperature for the SBO epoxidation reaction was 60 °C. It was also found that the catalyst had good catalytic activity as well as high selectivity for this reaction. 3.3.3 Recyclability of the catalyst The recoverability of the catalyst was a critical factor for choosing a non-homogeneous catalyst for SBO epoxidation. We conducted multiple experiments on the same catalyst to study its recovery properties. In the presence of a catalyst (mass ratio 1/100), SBO reacted with an equimolar double-bonded amount of H2O2 (0.05 mol H2O2/10 g SBO) at 60 °C for 3 h. Because of the small amount of catalyst used, we observed the separation of the catalyst from the two phases by placing the mixture in a centrifuge for centrifugal separation (Fig. 6d). This mixture was then filtered and washed with hexane, CH3CH2OH, and deionized water, respectively, and dried it in a vacuum drying oven (93.6% recovery). As shown in Fig. 6c, the recovered catalyst was tested again, and it maintained a high level of catalytic performance (92.1% conversion) after five cycles. Additionally, a leaching study was conducted to evaluate the catalyst's stability. We analyzed the reaction filtrate after filtering the solid catalyst by inductively coupled plasma-atomic emission spectrometry (ICP-AES). The results revealed a limited leaching of approximately 2.2% of the total W in the reaction medium, which may explain the gradual decline in activity that was observed during the recovery experiments. 3.3.4 Substrate scope of catalyst epoxidation To extend the scope of the reaction, we selected two fatty acids, linoleic acid, and ricinoleic acid, for epoxidation with the catalyst, and the results showed excellent conversion and selectivity were obtained with the catalyst. Furthermore, we tested small-molecule olefins to demonstrate the effectiveness of the catalysts designed for large lipophilic substrates. It is noteworthy that cyclooctane is the most commonly used substrate in phosphotungstic acid-catalyzed epoxidation reactions [71–73], and excellent conversion rates and selectivity were achieved with this substrate (Scheme 2 ). Using a catalyst-to-cyclooctene mass ratio of 1/10, we achieved full selectivity for epoxy cyclooctene with 99% conversion at 55 °C for 3 h. Additionally, the catalyst demonstrated high activity and selectivity for cyclohexene. Due to the presence of catalyst, 1,2-epoxycyclohexene would undergo rapid hydrolysis, leading to the formation of cyclohexane diol, which is strongly dependent on the reaction temperature [38]. We also tested the epoxidation reaction of allyl chloride in the presence of chlorine atoms, which showed a conversion of 97.1% and a selectivity of 99% for allyl chloride at a catalyst-to-allyl chloride mass ratio of 1/10, a reaction time of 3 h, and a temperature of 55 °C. 3.3.5 Advantages of catalysts in comparison to literature Quaternary ammonium salts serve as crucial phase transfer agents, playing a pivotal role in improving the solubility and stability of {PO4[W(O)(O2)2]4}3− in the organic phase. Within the literature, phase transfer catalysts utilizing {PO4[W(O)(O2)2]4}3− as the active intermediate are widely employed for selective epoxidation reactions involving vegetable oils and their derivatives [57,65,74]. In Table 3 , the reaction conditions and outcomes of various phase transfer catalysts utilized for the epoxidation of vegetable oils and their derivatives are presented. The catalysts developed in this study showed outstanding catalytic performance, along with a significant reduction in the required amount of reactants and catalysts for the epoxidation of SBO. Additionally, the enhanced recoverability of the catalyst significantly lowers production costs, highlighting its favorable economics. 3.4 Catalytic mechanism To investigate the catalytic mechanism, we tracked the catalyst in different stages of SBO epoxidation using the FT-IR spectroscopy (Fig. 7 a). We observed that when only the catalyst and SBO were present in the reaction system, the O-O peak at 841 cm−1 belonging to the catalyst disappeared, indicating that a transfer of reactive oxygen species had occurred. After the addition of hydrogen peroxide to the reaction system, the O-O peak at 841 cm−1 reappeared, and although the positions of both the W(O)2 and W=O peaks located at 549 and 953 cm−1, respectively, were shifted, we still observed an increase in W(O)2 peak intensity and a decrease in the W=O peak intensity. These results indicated that H2O2 was activated to form peroxides W-(η2-O2)) on the catalyst [75] and further illustrate that reactive oxygen successfully transferred from H2O2 to the catalyst [76]. As the reaction progressed, the intensity of the O-O peak belonging to the catalyst gradually decreased. Similarly, we traced the organic phase via FT-IR spectroscopy using the same approach for the different stages as mentioned earlier (Fig. 7b). The spectral changes of the v(C-H) bond connected to the double bond at 3008 cm−1 and the epoxy bond band at 823 cm−1 indicated the relevant O-atom transfer from W-(η2-O2)) intermediates to the C=C bond. The active oxygen on the catalyst was ultimately transferred to the organic phase [77]. Therefore, the prepared catalyst acted as an oxygen carrier in SBO epoxidation, transferring reactive oxygen from H2O2 to SBO, as shown in Scheme 3 . 3.5 Catalytic kinetic and thermodynamic study For studying the kinetics of the liquid/liquid reaction at an individual level, the main challenge was identifying the rate-determining step [56,78]. The mass transfer rate (or reaction rate) for diffusion-determined reactions should be linearly related to the stirring rate for the same interface area. However, if a plateau appears in the rating diagram, it indicates that the system's rate-controlling step is a chemical reaction. In the case of SBO epoxidation with a catalyst at the oil-water phases interface, investigating this reaction's rate-determining step and interfacial properties is crucial. Firstly, we investigated the effect of stirring speed on the rate of the SBO epoxidation reaction. As shown in Fig. 8 a, the concentration of epoxy group (EG) in SBO gradually increased with the progression of the reaction time at different stirring speeds. Fig. 8b depicts the reaction rate as a function of the stirring speed, which increased with a faster stirring speed within 50–250 rpm and peaked at 250 rpm. Thus, the interface reaction was the rate-determining step since the plateau phenomenon was observed in the rate diagram. Next, we explored the interfacial properties of the catalyst by studying the influence of catalyst dosage on different reaction rates. The catalyst-to-SBO mass ratios were set to 1/50, 1/75, 1/100, 1/150, and 1/200. As shown in Fig. 9 a, the concentration of the epoxy group (EG) gradually increased with the reaction time. Fig. 9b shows a plot of the reaction rate versus the catalyst dosage. The reaction rate increased gradually as the mass ratio of the catalyst to SBO increased, indicating the catalyst's significant interfacial activity. Furthermore, we investigated the kinetic and thermodynamic parameters of the SBO epoxidation process using the catalyst. The epoxidation reactions were carried out at 40, 50, and 60 °C under the following reaction conditions: 1:5 molar ratio of SBO to H2O2, 1 wt% catalyst weight, reaction time of 180 min, and stirring speed of 300 rpm. The ESO conversion was calculated every 30 min interval and used to determine the X E S O value of Eq. 9. The respective rate constants were determined by fitting the linear relationship between − l n ( 1 − X E S O ) versus t (min) at different temperatures. Fig. 10 a displays the kinetic fit for different reaction temperatures, demonstrating that the reaction rate depends only on the amount of double bonds in SBO. The regression values for all three curves ranged from 0.986 to 0.994, indicating that the assumed pseudo-first-order kinetic model for the SBO epoxidation reaction was valid. Table 4 summarizes the obtained rate constants, which were 0.0252, 0.0099, and 0.0038 min−1 at 60, 50, and 40 °C, respectively. These results indicate that the reaction rates will increase by 2-3-fold when the temperature was increased by 10–20 °C. Finally, we determined the activation energy ( E a )) and frequency factor ( A ) using the Arrhenius equation (Eq. 10). A higher value of E a (82.03 kJ/mol) suggests that small temperature changes can significantly impact the rate of epoxidation. The high-frequency factor A (1.82 × 1011 min−1) implies that intermolecular collisions in the SBO epoxidation reaction were highly successful. We then calculated the thermodynamic parameters by preparing plots of l n ( k / T ) versus 1 / T according to Eq. 10, as shown in Fig. 10b. The high coefficient of determination (0.9998) indicates that the relationship between reaction temperature and SBO epoxidation was well-established. Table 5 summarizes the obtained Gibb's free energy of activation ( Δ G # ) values at various temperatures using Eq. 12. The positive values of ΔG and ΔH, along with the negative value of ΔS, suggest that the SBO epoxidation reaction using the catalyst is non-spontaneous, endergonic, and is an endothermic process. 4 Conclusions In summary, we have developed a phase transfer catalyst [(C18H37)2(CH3)2N]3{PO4[W(O)(O2)2]4} that is recyclable, easily synthesized, and offers excellent selectivity for the solvent-free epoxidation of SBO with H2O2. The optimized reaction conditions resulted in a maximum conversion of 98.6% and selectivity above 99%. FT-IR spectroscopy investigations confirmed that the catalyst acted as a reactive oxygen carrier, transferring reactive oxygen from H2O2 to SBO. Recovery experiments revealed that the catalyst remained active at 92.1% after 5 cycles, highlighting its sustainability in ESO production. Through fitting of the kinetic and thermodynamic experimental data, we determined that the reaction rate constant (0.0252 min−1) was similar to that of the homogeneous catalyst, while the values of Δ G # (92.12 kJ mol−1), Δ H # (79.35 kJ mol−1), and Δ S # (-38.52 J K−1 mol−1) indicated that the reaction was non-spontaneous, endergonic, and endothermic. Moreover, the catalyst exhibited excellent activity, selectivity, recoverability, and versatility in epoxidation reactions of unsaturated oils and olefins. Considering all these aspects, this phase transfer catalyst is an ideal option for green, safe, and sustainable production of ESO. In addition, this research provided helpful guidelines for the catalysis of other unsaturated olefin epoxidation reactions. coredata.dc:description: Epoxidized soybean oil (ESO) is a vital organic renewable chemical material widely used in the preparation of biomaterials. In this paper, a novel amphiphilic phase transfer catalyst [(C18H37)2(CH3)2N]3{PO4[W(O)(O2)2]4} was developed to facilitate the green, safe and sustainable production of ESO, with the aim of achieving maximum environmental and economic benefits. Soybean oil (SBO) was epoxidized into ESO at a conversion rate of 98.6% and the selectivity of this process was above 99% with H2O2 as the oxidant. The catalyst was easily separable through filtration after the reaction, and its activity was found to be consistently maintained after 5 cycles. The developed catalysts were characterized via various physical means such as Fourier-transform infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopy, X-ray diffraction (XRD), and scanning electron microscopy (SEM), while the catalytic mechanism was explored using FT-IR spectroscopy. Several kinetic and thermodynamic experiments suggested that the developed catalyst possessed significant interfacial activity and the process followed a non-spontaneous endothermic pathway.
coredata.dc:title: A novel amphiphilic phase transfer catalyst for the green epoxidation of soybean oil with hydrogen peroxide
